page.title: Blasphemy law in the Republic of Ireland

revision.comment: Added link to Vladimir_Pecherin
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} In the [[state of Ireland]], '''blasphemy''' is prohibited against any form of religion.<ref>https://scholarlycommons.law.case.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.com/&httpsredir=1&article=1134&context=jil</ref> Originally, it was limited to Christianity and was required to be prohibited by Article 40.6.1.i. of the [[Constitution of Ireland|1937 Constitution]]. The [[common law]] [[offence (law)|offence]] of [[blasphemous libel]], applicable only to Christianity and last prosecuted unsuccessfully in [[Vladimir_Pecherin|1855]],<ref name="iesc5s24"/>{{#tag:ref|An alleged instance in 1909 appears to relate not to a prosecution for blasphemy but to an ice rink operator's application to the [[Recorder of Dublin]] for renewal of its entertainment licence. It was alleged that a previous patron had skated while dressed as a parody of Jesus. The operator had objected to the costume and licence was granted.<ref>O'Higgins 1960, p.164</ref> A 1957 prosecution for [[profanity]], discussed in the [[#RoseTattoo|Independence]] section of this article, assumed that "profanity" meant "[[obscenity]]" rather than "blasphemy".<ref>O'Higgins 1960, p.151–152</ref>|group="n"}} was ruled in 1999 to be incompatible with the Constitution's guarantee of religious equality. The [[lacuna (law)|deficit]] was filled in 2009 by a new offence of "publication or utterance of blasphemous matter", against any religion. The continued existence of a [[blasphemy]] offence is controversial, with proponents of [[freedom of speech]] and [[freedom of religion]] arguing it should be removed.<ref name="conv2014p4"/> The [[Government of the 32nd Dáil|government formed in 2016]] has committed to holding a referendum on abolishing the constitutional offence, which is required to amend the constitution.<ref name="Programme_for_Partnership_Government">{{cite web|url=http://www.merrionstreet.ie/MerrionStreet/en/ImageLibrary/Programme_for_Partnership_Government.pdf#page=154 |format=PDF|title=A Programme for a Partnership Government|date=11 May 2016|publisher=Government of Ireland|page=153|accessdate=1 June 2016 |quote=We propose that a number of referenda be held. These include ... amending Article 40.6.1(i) of the Constitution to remove the offence of blasphemy }}</ref> [[Thirty-seventh Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018|This referendum]] was held on 26 October 2018.<ref name="rte988011">{{cite news |title=Presidential Election to be held on 26 October |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/politics/2018/0828/988011-presidential-election/ |accessdate=5 September 2018 |work=RTE.ie |date=28 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref> Results showed the amendment to remove the blasphemy offense from the Irish Constitution passed by a margin of 64.85% to 35.15%.<ref name=rteoct27>https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/1027/1007130-blasphemy-referendum/</ref> However, this does not repeal the 2009 Defamation Act, which enforces a fine of up to 25,000 euros (about $28,500) for blasphemy.<ref name=2009blas>https://www.local10.com/news/international/ireland-awaits-result-in-referendum-on-repealing-blasphemy-ban</ref>
==Early history== The [[Law of Ireland|legal system of Ireland]] grew out of the [[common law]] system of [[English law]], and so Irish jurisprudence on blasphemy largely reflected [[Blasphemy law in the United Kingdom#England and Wales|that of England]]. The common law offence of blasphemous libel applied only to Christianity.<ref>Keane 1991, §§92,104</ref> Blasphemy could be committed by written or spoken words, by pictures or gestures.<ref>Keane 1991, §108</ref> [[Profanity]] was generally regarded by legal scholars as synonymous with blasphemy.<ref>O'Higgins 1960, p.151</ref> In 1328, [[Adam Duff O'Toole]] was [[burned alive]] in Dublin for alleged [[heresy]] and blasphemy.<ref name="callan2015"/> Initially tried under [[canon law]], he was handed over to the civil power as a repeat offender.<ref name="callan2015"/> He was a member of the [[O'Toole family]] which launched [[Gaelic Ireland|Gaelic]] raids on [[the Pale|the Anglo-Norman Pale]], and modern historians regard the charges as politically motivated.<ref name="callan2015">{{cite book |chapter=The heresy of being Irish : Adducc Dubh O'Toole and two MacConmaras |first=Maeve Brigid |last=Callan |title=The Templars, the witch, and the wild Irish : vengeance and heresy in medieval Ireland |publisher=Cornell University Press |year=2015 }}</ref> In later times, the penalty for a first offence of blasphemous libel was an unlimited fine and imprisonment; for a second offence it was [[banishment]].<ref name="dail1961">[http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0191/D.0191.196107260066.html Defamation Bill, 1961—Committee Stage] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609123352/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/D/0191/D.0191.196107260066.html |date=9 June 2011 }} Dáil Éireann – Volume 191 – 26 July 1961</ref> The [[Anglican]] [[Church of Ireland]] was the [[established church]] from 1536 to [[Irish Church Act 1869|1871]]. Whether the crime could be committed against a [[Christian denomination|denomination]] other than the established church was unclear;<ref name="seanad2008">[http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0188/S.0188.200803110005.html Defamation Bill 2006: Report and Final Stages.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609123531/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0188/S.0188.200803110005.html |date=9 June 2011 }} Seanad Éireann – Volume 188 – 11 March 2008</ref> [[John M. Kelly (politician)|John Kelly]] suggested not.<ref name="jcom40.6.1.i"/>
An act of 1634–5 made it an offence "profanely swear or curse";<ref>10–11 Car. 1 c.1; ''Stat Parl Irl'' [https://books.google.ie/books?id=ymlBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA275 v.2 pp.275–276]</ref> this was replaced as "ineffectual" by the Profane Oaths Act 1695,<ref>7 Will 3 c.9; ''Stat Parl Irl'' [https://books.google.ie/books?id=QYFRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA257 v.3 pp.257–259]</ref> which applied to profanity in the presence of a [[justice of the peace]] or mayor.<ref name="lrc34">{{cite book |url=http://www.lawreform.ie/_fileupload/Reports/rOaths.htm |title=Report on Oaths and Affirmation |series=LRC |volume=34–1990 |author=Law Reform Commission |date=December 1990 |accessdate=27 October 2017 |chapter=Appendix B: Profane Oaths And Unlawful Oaths |pages=47–48 }}</ref> It had fallen into disuse long before its repeal in 2007.<ref name="lrc34"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/isbc/pui1695.html|title=Pre-Union Irish Statutes Affected : 1695|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=27 October 2017}}</ref> Six [[bill (law)|bills]] to suppress "blasphemy and profaneness" were introduced in the [[Parliament of Ireland]] between 1697 and 1713, but none was passed into law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qub.ac.uk/ild/?func=advanced_search&search=true&bill_number=&search_string=&search_string_type=ALL&search_type=any&session_from=1692&session_to=1800&enacted_search=all&subjects=606|title=Bills with subject of "Moral regulation, inc. prostitution, gambling etc"|work=Irish Legislation Database|publisher=[[Queens University Belfast]]|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref>
There was a prosecution in the [[Kingdom of Ireland]] for blasphemous libel in 1703: [[Thomas Emlyn]], a [[Unitarianism|Unitarian]] minister, was fined £1,000 and imprisoned for one year for denying the [[Divinity of Christ]].<ref>Keane 1991, §14</ref> He remained in [[debtor's prison]] after his initial sentence until the fine was reduced to £70.<ref>{{cite book|last=Gordon |first=Alexander |authorlink=Alexander Gordon (Unitarian)|title=Dictionary of National Biography|chapterurl=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Emlyn,_Thomas_(DNB00)|volume=17|year=1889|publisher=[[Smith, Elder & Co.]]|chapter=Emlyn, Thomas}}</ref> [[Narcissus Marsh]], the [[Archbishop of Dublin (Church of Ireland)|Church of Ireland Archbishop of Dublin]], began a prosecution against a [[Presbyterianism in Ireland|Presbyterian]] minister in Drogheda, which was dropped by the [[Dublin Castle administration]] sympathetic to [[dissenter]]s.<ref>{{Cite ODNB|id=101018115|title=Narcissus Marsh}}</ref> Other incidents that century did not result in prosecutions. In 1713, [[Peter Browne (theologian)|Peter Browne]], [[bishop of Cork and Ross]] preached that [[loyal toast]]s to "the glorious, pious, and immortal memory" of [[William III of England|King William]] were blasphemous.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Powell |first=Martyn J. |date=13 October 2006 |title=Political Toasting in Eighteenth-Century Ireland |journal=History |publisher=The Historical Association and Blackwell Publishing |volume=91 |issue=304 |pages=508–529 |doi=10.1111/j.1468-229X.2006.00376.x }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |authorlink=William Edward Hartpole Lecky |last=Lecky |first=William Edward Hartpole |title=A history of Ireland in the eighteenth century |publisher=Longmans, Green & Co |location=London |year=1918 |volume=1 |page=423 |isbn=0-543-95021-2 |url=https://archive.org/stream/historyofireland01leckuoft#page/422/mode/2up }}</ref> The same year, a [[convocation]] of the Church of Ireland recommended prosecution of [[Robert Molesworth, 1st Viscount Molesworth|Robert Molesworth]] for "an indictable profanation of the holy scriptures", after he had quoted Scripture in the course of an insult to their representatives at a [[Lord Lieutenant of Ireland|viceregal]] [[Levée (event)|levée]].<ref name="hayton">{{cite book |last=Hayton |first=David |title=Ruling Ireland, 1685–1742: politics, politicians and parties |publisher=Boydell Press |year=2004 |series=Irish historical monographs |volume=1 |pages=179–180 |isbn=1-84383-058-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=izGm9rqaoFcC&lpg=PA180&ots=7U8qZM5MS3&dq=1713%20blasphemy%20ireland&pg=PA179#v=onepage&q=1713%20blasphemy%20ireland&f=false }}</ref><ref>Levy, p.276</ref> In 1756, Robert Clayton, [[Bishop of Clogher]], questioned the [[Nicene Creed]] in a tract on [[religious tolerance]]; he was condemned by other bishops, but died before any prosecution for blasphemy was brought.<ref>Levy, pp.276–7</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=A New and General Biographical Dictionary, containing an historical, critical and impartial account of the lives and writings of the most eminent persons in every nation in the world, particularly the British and Irish, from the earliest accounts of time to the present period |location=London |year=1795 |edition=New |volume=3 |pages=369–71 |chapter=Clayton (Robert) |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K6EDAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA370&ots=xJbuhwRO37&dq=bishop%201756%20%22nicene%20creed%22%20%22church%20of%20ireland%22&pg=PA370#v=onepage&q=bishop%201756%20%22nicene%20creed%22%20%22church%20of%20ireland%22&f=false }}</ref>
In 1852, in the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]], John Syngean Bridgman, a [[Franciscan]] friar, was convicted in [[County Mayo]] after [[Book burning|burning]] an [[Authorized King James Version|Authorized King James Bible]].<ref name="lawreform15">Keane 1991, §15</ref> He viewed it as a [[souperism|souperist]] work inferior to the Catholic [[Douay-Rheims Bible]]. While the indictment described his actions as "in contempt of the Protestant religion", Judge [[Thomas Langlois Lefroy]] advised the jury "it is not the [[Bible version debate|version of the Scriptures]] which will warrant the commission of such an offence" but rather "a want of reverence to the Scriptures".<ref name="lawreform15"/><ref name="Levy">Levy, p.464</ref> In 1855 at [[Dún Laoghaire|Kingstown]], a Protestant Bible was burned on a bonfire of "irreligious" books organised by Vladimir Petcherine, a [[Redemptorist]] Catholic priest. He was acquitted of blasphemy after claiming he had not intended to burn any Bibles.<ref name="lawreform15"/><ref name="Levy"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Doyle|first=James|title=A special report of the trial of the Rev. Vladimir Petcherine : (one of the Redemptorist fathers), in the Court House, Green-Street, Dublin, December, 1855, on an indictment charging him with burning the Protestant Bible at Kingstown|url=https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/100606510|accessdate=29 April 2016|date=1856 |publisher=James Duffy|location=Dublin }}</ref> The case, described by as David Lawton as banal and petty, was prosecuted by the [[Attorney-General for Ireland]] and the [[Solicitor-General for Ireland]] after a complaint from [[Methodism in Ireland|Methodist]] minister Robert Wallace.<ref name="Lawton1993">{{cite book|last=Lawton|first=David|title=Blasphemy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=twcSyyujZ0wC&pg=PA116|accessdate=29 April 2016|date=1993-07-01|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|isbn=9780812215038|pages=112, 116}}</ref><ref name="Kingstown.)1855">{{cite book|last=Wallace|first=Robert |title=A voice from the fire: a sermon occasioned by the public burning of the Bible at Kingstown, by the Redemptorist Fathers, on the 5th of November, 1855|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qw1hAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA1|accessdate=29 April 2016|year=1855|publisher=John Robertson }}</ref>
==Independence== [[Reception statute|Common law precedents persisted]] after the creation in 1922 of the [[Irish Free State]], provided they were consistent with the [[Constitution of the Irish Free State|1922 Constitution]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1922/en/act/pub/0001/sched1.html|title=Constitution of the Irish Free State |date=6 December 1922|work=[[Irish Statute Book]] |page=Article 73 |nopp=Y |accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> and later the [[Constitution of Ireland|current (1937) Constitution]].<ref>Constitution of Ireland, [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/en/constitution/index.html#article50_1 Article 50.1]</ref> The last British prosecution till [[Whitehouse v Lemon|1977]] was ''Bowman v Secular Society Limited'' in 1917.<ref name="lawreform16">Keane 1991, §16</ref> The Irish [[Law Reform Commission]]'s 1991 consultation paper on the crime of [[libel]] states, "if a case had arisen between Bowman in 1917 and 1937, it seems likely that an Irish court would have found the views in Bowman persuasive".<ref name="lawreform16"/>{{what|date=September 2018}}
The 1937 Constitution states "The publication or utterance of blasphemous, seditious or indecent matter is an offence which shall be punishable in accordance with law"<ref name="const_40_6_1_i"/>{{#tag:ref| Seditious publications are prohibited by the [[Offences against the State Act 1939]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1939/act/13/enacted/en/print#sec10|title=Offences Against the State Act, 1939|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=31 October 2017|nopp=Y |pages=sections 10(1)(c) and 12}}</ref> Indecent publications are prohibited under the Censorship of Publications Acts, 1929 and 1946.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1929/act/21/enacted/en/print#sec17|title=Censorship of Publications Act, 1929|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|pages=sections 17–19 |nopp=Y|accessdate=31 October 2017}}; {{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1946/act/1/enacted/en/print#sec7|title=Censorship of Publications Act, 1946|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|pages=sections 7 and 9 |nopp=Y|accessdate=31 October 2017}}</ref> The common law offences of [[seditious libel]] and [[obscene libel]] were abolished by the Defamation Act 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/2009/act/31/section/35/enacted/en/html|title=Defamation Act 2009, Section 35|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=31 October 2017}}</ref> |group="n"}} and "The State acknowledges that the homage of public worship is due to Almighty God. It shall hold His Name in reverence, and shall respect and honour religion."<ref>Constitution of Ireland, [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/en/constitution/index.html#article44_1 Article 44.1]</ref> The Constitution also guarantees certain rights "subject to public order and morality", including citizens' right "to express freely their convictions and opinions"<ref name="const_40_6_1_i">Constitution of Ireland, [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/en/constitution/index.html#article40_6_1 Article 40.6.1.i.]</ref> and "[f]reedom of conscience and the free profession and practice of religion".<ref>Constitution of Ireland, [http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/en/constitution/index.html#article44_2_1 Article 44.2.1°]</ref> In 1960, Paul O'Higgins criticised the 1937 Constitution's blasphemy provision as introducing uncertainty, and possibly increased stricture, compared to the common law as developed to that date.<ref>O'Higgins 1960, p.166</ref>
{{anchor|RoseTattoo}}In 1957, ''[[The Rose Tattoo]]'' was produced at the inaugural [[Dublin Theatre Festival]]. Alan Simpson, owner of the Pike Theatre Club, was prosecuted for "producing for gain an [[obscenity|indecent]] and profane performance", with [[obscenity]] later added to the charge.<ref>Keane 1991, §§128–132</ref> The play's detractors were concerned by its sexual content rather than religion.<ref name="trotter">{{cite book|last=Trotter |first=Mary |title=Modern Irish Theatre |publisher=Polity |year=2008 |series=Cultural history of literature |volume=11 |pages=134–5 |isbn=0-7456-3343-9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AZCIfwnzo7UC&lpg=PT146&ots=pGkHo8jOWG&dq=dublin%201957%20%22The%20Rose%20Tattoo%22&pg=PT146#v=onepage&q=dublin%201957%20%22The%20Rose%20Tattoo%22&f=false }}</ref> The Law Reform Commission's 1991 report comments "the equation of indecency and obscenity with profanity is probably misconceived. Although profane matter may sometimes be obscene or indecent, it is not necessarily so."<ref>Keane 1991, §131</ref>
Section 13 of the Defamation Act, 1961 prescribed penalties for blasphemous libel, but did not define the offence,<ref name="act1961">[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1961/en/act/pub/0040/sec0013.html#zza40y1961s13 Defamation Act, 1961, Section 13] [[Irish Statute Book]]</ref> which was presumed still to be the common-law offence.<ref name="dail1961"/> The new maximum penalties were seven years' [[penal servitude]], or two years' [[imprisonment]] and a £500 fine.<ref name="act1961"/>
===''Corway v. Independent Newspapers''=== The only attempted prosecution since 1855 was in 1995–1999,<ref name="iesc5s24">[1999] IESC 5 §24</ref><ref name="it3075884">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/martyn-turner-s-1995-court-date-for-blasphemy-1.3075884|title=Martyn Turner’s 1995 court date for blasphemy|last=Turner|first=Martyn|date=9 May 2017|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=9 May 2017}}</ref> when John Corway brought [[private prosecution]]s against three publications for coverage of [[Fifteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|the 1995 divorce referendum]], specifically an article in ''[[Hot Press]]'' and two [[editorial cartoon]]s, by Wendy Shea in the ''[[Irish Independent]]'' and [[Martyn Turner]] in ''[[The Irish Times]]''.<ref name="it98866">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/blasphemy-case-against-independent-lost-1.98866|title=Blasphemy case against Independent lost|date=24 October 1996|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=9 May 2017}}</ref> The original cases were dismissed because of the lack of a definition of the crime of blasphemy,<ref name="it3075884"/> with that against [[Independent News & Media|Independent Newspapers]] and editor [[Aengus Fanning]] appealed as a [[Test case (law)|test case]] to the [[High Court (Ireland)|High Court]].<ref name="it98866"/> Shea's cartoon depicted the [[24th Government of Ireland|government parties]]' leaders snubbing a [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|Catholic priest]] who was holding out a [[Eucharist in the Catholic Church|Communion wafer]].<ref>[1999] IESC 5 §5</ref> Corway submitted, "As one professing and endeavouring to practise the Christian religion through membership of the Roman Catholic Church I have suffered offence and outrage by reason of the insult, ridicule and contempt shown towards the sacrament of the Eucharist as a result of the publication of the matter complained of herein and I am aware of other persons having also so suffered."<ref>[1999] IESC 5 §7</ref>
High Court Justice [[Hugh Geoghegan]] ruled against Corway on the basis that there was no ''[[actus reus]]'', although there would have been ''[[mens rea]]''.<ref name="it98866"/><ref>[1999] IESC 5 §9</ref> He also said he would not have given [[leave to prosecute]] as it would not serve the [[public interest]].<ref name="it98866"/> Corway appealed the decision to the [[Supreme Court (Ireland)|Supreme Court]], which upheld it.<ref>[1999] IESC 5 §41</ref> It ruled that the 1937 Constitution had extinguished the common law offence, stating "It is difficult to see how the common law crime of blasphemy, related as it was to an established Church and an established religion, could survive in ... a Constitution guaranteeing freedom of conscience, and the free profession and practice of religion."<ref>[1999] IESC 5 §35</ref> It refused to allow the prosecution, stating "in the absence of any legislative definition of the constitutional offence of blasphemy, it is impossible to say of what the offence of blasphemy consists ... neither the ''actus reus'' nor the ''mens rea'' is clear. ... In the absence of legislation and in the present uncertain state of the law the Court could not see its way to authorising the institution of a criminal prosecution."<ref>[1999] IESC 5 §38</ref>
==Defamation Act 2009== The Law Reform Commission's 1991 Report opined that "there is no place for the offence of blasphemous libel in a society which respects freedom of speech".<ref name="lawreform231">Keane 1991, §231</ref> It said the Prohibition of [[Incitement to Hatred]] Act 1989 provided an adequate protection for outrage against religious belief.<ref name="lawreform231"/> However, since banning blasphemy is mandated by the Constitution, abolishing the offence would require a [[referendum]]. A referendum solely for that purpose "would rightly be seen as a time wasting and expensive exercise".<ref>Keane 1991, §232</ref> The Commission's report, therefore, outlined criteria for a statutory definition of blasphemy which could serve until such time as Article 40.6.1.i might be changed as part of a broader Constitutional amendment.<ref>Keane 1991, §245</ref> The 1996 report of the [[Oireachtas]] Constitution Review Group agreed that "The retention of the present constitutional offence of blasphemy is not appropriate."<ref>[http://www.constitution.ie/reports/crg.pdf Report of the Constitution Review Group, 1996] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721123405/http://www.constitution.ie/reports/crg.pdf |date=21 July 2011 }}</ref>
The Defamation Act 2009 (introduced as the Defamation Bill 2006)<ref name="defbill2006">{{cite web |url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/viewdoc.asp?fn=/documents/bills28/bills/2006/4306/document1.htm |title=Defamation Bill 2006 [Seanad] (No.43 of 2006) |publisher=Houses of the Oireachtas}}</ref> implemented many of the recommendations of the Commission's 1991 report. The bill [[first reading|as introduced]] omitted reference to blasphemy, pending a review by the Oireachtas [[Joint Committee]] on the Constitution. In March 2008, [[Brian Lenihan Jnr|Brian Lenihan]], then [[Minister for Justice and Equality|Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform]], said:<ref name="seanad2008"/>
{{quote|In England and Wales blasphemy traditionally only consisted in the scandalising of the established church. It is probably the case in Ireland, with the enactment of the Article 44 provision in 1937, that blasphemy was extended to cover all of the denominations recognised in the Constitution and that [[Fifth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|in 1972]] it passed into a stage where it extended itself to all [[theism|theistic]] religions, since all theistic religions are honoured by the Constitution, although Christianity is uniquely invoked in the preamble.}}
The Joint Committee on the Constitution's report on Article 40.6.1.i. was published in July 2008. The Committee had discussed the case of comedian [[Tommy Tiernan]], whose stand-up routine on ''[[The Late Late Show (Ireland)|The Late Late Show]]'' parodied the Gospels, offending many viewers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://debates.oireachtas.ie/DDebate.aspx?F=CNJ20080423.xml&Node=29|title=Joint Committee on the Constitution|date=23 April 2008|work=Parliamentary Debates|publisher=Oireachtas|accessdate=23 October 2010 |page=2}}</ref> The [[Bar Council of Ireland]] made a presentation to the Committee, pointing out that blasphemy and [[treason]] were the only crimes specifically mentioned in the Constitution.<ref name="CommissionMeeting1">{{cite web|url=http://debates.oireachtas.ie/DDebate.aspx?F=CNJ20080423.xml&Node=163|title=JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE CONSTITUTION|date=23 April 2008|work=Parliamentary Debates|page=1|accessdate=23 October 2010}}</ref> Neville Cox stated:<ref name="CommissionMeeting1" />
{{quote|When the English Parliament originally enacted blasphemy laws, it was with a view to appeasing an angry God who was irritated by despicable literature and who was causing plagues and fires to occur in London. That was the historical reason for the law. The [[Law Commission (England and Wales)|Law Commission in England]] suggested that there were two types of situation where what had previously been characterised as blasphemous material might generate a public interest in its prohibition. The first is where there is incitement to hatred and the second is where there is simply an excessive offence to religious sensibilities. The term "blasphemy" does not relate to either of these. It is, therefore, a misdescription of a changed law.}}
The Oireachtas Committee's report concluded:<ref name="jcom40.6.1.i">{{cite web|url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/documents/committees30thdail/j-constitution/report_2008/100708-Report1.pdf |title=First Report Article 40.6.1.i – Freedom of Expression |last=Joint Committee on the Constitution |date=July 2008|publisher=Houses of the Oireachtas |accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref>
{{quote|The reference itself has effectively been rendered a "dead letter" by virtue of the decision of the Supreme Court in ''Corway''. Furthermore, the Committee is of the view that in a modern Constitution, blasphemy is not a phenomenon against which there should be an express constitutional prohibition.}}
On 20 May 2009 at the Bill's [[committee stage]], section 36, dealing with blasphemy was introduced by Minister for Justice [[Dermot Ahern]] as an amendment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/Debates%20Authoring/DebatesWebPack.nsf/committeetakes/JUS2009052000004#N100|title=Defamation Bill 2006 [Seanad]: Committee Stage (Resumed).|date=20 May 2009|work=Select Committee on Justice, Equality, Defence and Women's Rights proceedings|pages=New Section |nopp=Y|accessdate=29 April 2016}}; {{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/Debates%20Authoring/DebatesWebPack.nsf/committeetakes/JUS2009070100004|title=Defamation Bill 2006 [Seanad]: Committee Stage (Resumed).|date=1 July 2009|work=Select Committee on Justice, Equality, Defence and Women's Rights|accessdate=29 April 2016}}</ref> Section 36 defines a new [[indictable offence]] of "Publication or utterance of blasphemous matter",<ref name="act2009n31s36">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2009/en/act/pub/0031/sec0036.html |title=36. Publication or utterance of blasphemous matter. |work=Defamation Act 2009 |accessdate=29 April 2009}}</ref> which carries a maximum fine of €25,000.<ref name="act2009n31s36"/> The offence consists of uttering material "grossly abusive or insulting in relation to matters held sacred by any religion", when the intent and result is "outrage among a substantial number of the adherents of that religion".<ref name="act2009n31s36"/> A [[Defense (legal)|defence]] is permitted for work of "genuine literary, artistic, political, scientific, or academic value".<ref name="act2009n31s36"/> "Religion" excludes profit-driven organisations or those using "oppressive [[psychological manipulation]]".<ref name="act2009n31s36"/> Upon conviction under section 36, a court [[Warrant (law)|warrant]] can authorise the [[Garda Síochána]] (police) to enter premises to search for and seize any copies of the blasphemous material.<ref name="act2009n31s37">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2009/en/act/pub/0031/sec0037.html |title=37. Seizure of copies of blasphemous statements. |work=Defamation Act 2009 |accessdate=29 April 2009}}</ref> Only the [[Director of Public Prosecutions (Ireland)|Director of Public Prosecutions]] (DPP) can instigate proceedings, as distinct from private prosecutions like ''Corway''. <ref name="dail20170509">{{cite web|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/debates/?id=2017-05-09a.47#g99|title=Order of Business|date=9 May 2017|work=Dáil debates|publisher=KildareStreet.com|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> Ahern said:<ref>[http://www.inis.gov.ie/en/JELR/Pages/Amending%20the%20Law%20on%20Blasphemous%20Libel%20Speech%20by%20the%20Mr.%20Dermot%20Ahern%20T.D.,%20Minister%20for%20Justice,%20Equality%20and%20Law%20Reform%20at%20the%20Dail%20Committee%20on%20Justice,%20Equality%20Defence%20and%20Women%27s%20Rights%20Wednesday,%2020th%20May,%202009 Amending the Law on Blasphemous Libel] Dermot Ahern, Dáil , 20 May 2009</ref>
{{quote|I am ... puzzled as to the hysterical and incorrect reaction whipped up by some media reporters and commentators on this point. ... I as the responsible Minister, and we as legislators, do not have the luxury of pursuing a "do nothing" approach while we wait for an opportune moment to move a constitutional amendment.}}
[[Mary McAleese]], the [[President of Ireland]], convened the [[Council of State (Ireland)|Council of State]] to discuss whether the Bill should be referred to the Supreme Court to test its constitutionality; she decided not to do so.<ref name="Coulter17032010"/> The bill became law when McAleese [[signed into law|signed it]] on 23 July 2009,<ref name="defbill2006"/> and [[coming into force|came into force]] on 1 January 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/2009/si/517/made/en/print|title=S.I. No. 517/2009 - Defamation Act 2009 (Commencement) Order 2009|date=15 December 2009|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=31 July 2017}}</ref>
===Implementation=== {{As of|2017|May|9}} no prosecution has ever been brought under the 2009 act.<ref name="dail20170509"/>
The advocacy group [[Atheist Ireland]] responded to the enactment by announcing the formation of the "Church of Dermotology" (named after Dermot Ahern).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blasphemy.ie/2009/05/26/join-the-church-of-dermotology/ |title=Join the Church of Dermotology |first=Michael |last=Nugent |work=blasphemy.ie |publisher=Atheist Ireland |date=26 May 2009 |accessdate=18 January 2010 }}</ref> On the date on which the law came into effect, it published a series of potentially blasphemous quotations on its website and vowed to challenge any resulting legal action.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blasphemy.ie/2010/01/01/atheist-ireland-publishes-25-blasphemous-quotes/|title=Atheist Ireland Publishes 25 Blasphemous Quotes|last=Nugent|first=Michael|date=1 January 2010|work=blasphemy.ie|publisher=Atheist Ireland|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref>
After the 2015 [[Charlie Hebdo shooting|''Charlie Hebdo'' shooting]], Ali Selim of the [[Islamic Cultural Centre of Ireland]] suggested that the blasphemy provision of the Defamation Act 2009 should be applied to any media outlet reproducing cartoons [[Depictions of Muhammad|depicting Muhammad]] as part of the "[[Je suis Charlie]]" campaign.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/dr-ali-selim-charlie-hebdo-cartoon-1870437-Jan2015/|title=Muslim scholar could seek legal advice if Irish media republish Mohammed cartoon|last=Barry|first=Aoife|date=7 January 2015|work=[[TheJournal.ie]]|accessdate=15 April 2015}}</ref> In 2016, the Irish Secretary of the [[National Union of Journalists]] said that ''Charlie Hebdo'' would have been in "clear breach" of the Irish law.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/republic-s-blasphemy-laws-are-outdated-nuj-boss-says-1.2907802|title=Republic’s blasphemy laws are ‘outdated’, NUJ boss says|last=Gleeson|first=Colin|date=15 December 2016|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=16 December 2016}}</ref>
In 2016, Neville Cox said, "My view is the 2009 act fulfilled a constitutional obligation on the crime of blasphemy, but skilfully rendered the law completely unenforceable. I am not saying that was the intention".<ref name="it2807475"/> Dermot Ahern commented in 2017, "We implemented the crime but made it in a way that it would be virtually impossible to prosecute."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/we-made-blasphemy-law-almost-impossible-to-prosecute-former-minister-says-about-stephen-fry-garda-investigation-35690071.html|title=We made blasphemy law 'almost impossible to prosecute' - former minister says about Stephen Fry garda investigation|last=Nugent|first=Ryan|date=8 May 2017|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=8 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://podcast.rasset.ie/podcasts/audio/2017/0508/20170508_rteradio1-seanorourke-blasphemyl_c21169896_21169904_232_/20170508_rteradio1-seanorourke-blasphemyl_c21169896_21169904_232_.mp3 |format=MP3|title=Blasphemy Law: Dermot Ahern, Former F.F. Justice Minister |date=8 May 2017|work=Today with Sean O'Rourke|publisher=RTÉ|accessdate=8 May 2017}}</ref>
On 6 May 2017, the ''[[Irish Independent]]'' said an unnamed man informed them that the Garda were looking into a formal complaint of blasphemy he had made against [[Stephen Fry]] and [[RTÉ]] after Fry's 2015 appearance on RTÉ's religion programme ''[[The Meaning of Life (TV series)|The Meaning of Life]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/news/garda-launch-blasphemy-probe-into-stephen-fry-comments-on-the-meaning-of-life-35684262.html|title=Gardaí launch blasphemy probe into Stephen Fry comments on 'The Meaning of Life'|last=McMahon|first=Cathal|date=6 May 2017|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=8 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="ind35688328">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/news/explainer-why-is-stephen-fry-being-investigated-by-garda-for-blasphemy-and-what-happens-next-35688328.html|title=Explainer: Why is Stephen Fry being investigated by gardaí for blasphemy and what happens next?|last=McMahon|first=Cathal|date=7 May 2017|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=8 May 2017}}</ref>{{#tag:ref| When host [[Gay Byrne]] asked what he would say to God at the "[[pearly gates]]", Fry responded, "I'd say '[[Childhood cancer|Bone cancer in children]], what's that about?' How dare you create [[problem of evil|a world in which there is such misery that is not our fault]]. It's not right. It's utterly, utterly evil. Why should I respect a capricious, mean-minded, stupid god who creates a world which is so full of injustice and pain? ... the god who created this universe, if it was created by god, is quite clearly a maniac, an utter maniac, totally selfish."<ref name="ind35688328"/> |group="n"}} The complainant said that he was not personally offended by Fry's comments.<ref name="ind35688328"/> Unofficial Garda sources said that a file would be sent to the DPP, who was "highly unlikely" to prosecute.<ref name="ind35688328"/> On 8 May 2017, the Garda said they would not proceed with an investigation as no injured parties had come forward and they were "unable to find a substantial number of outraged people".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2017/0508/873562-stephen-fry-blasphemy/ |title=No investigation into alleged blasphemy by Stephen Fry |publisher=RTÉ |date=9 May 2017 |accessdate=9 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/stephen-fry-blasphemy-ireland-probe-investigation-dropped-police-gardai-not-enough-outrage-a7725116.html|title=Irish police drop Stephen Fry blasphemy investigation due to 'lack of outraged people'|date=2017-05-08|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-05-08|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/stephen-fry-blasphemy-probe-dropped-after-garda-fail-to-find-substantial-number-of-outraged-people-35692915.html|title=Stephen Fry blasphemy probe dropped after gardaí fail to find 'substantial number of outraged people'|last=McMahon|first=Cathal|date=8 May 2017|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=9 May 2017}}</ref> Fry later said he had "discovered from the person who actually framed the blasphemy law that it was deliberately framed in order to be unworkable." He thought it was a "wonderfully Irish solution" to the problem of outdated legislation that could not be repealed without a referendum that they "just engineer[ed] it a little so that it became preposterous."<ref>{{cite news |title=Stephen Fry says he was 'enchanted' to be caught up in blasphemy row |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/stephen-fry-blasphemy-2-3680301-Nov2017/ |accessdate=4 September 2018 |work=The Journal |date=4 November 2017}}</ref>
== 2018 referendum== {{main|Thirty-seventh Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018}} After the 2009 Act, Atheist Ireland said that it would be holding a series of public meetings to launch a campaign for secular constitutional reform.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jan/01/irish-atheists-challenge-blasphemy-law Irish atheists challenge new blasphemy laws] – The Guardian, Friday, 1 January 2010</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8437460.stm Irish atheists challenge blasphemy law] – BBC News, Saturday, 2 January 2010</ref> In March 2010, Ahern's press officer said the minister might ask [[Government of the 30th Dáil|the cabinet]] to hold a referendum to remove the reference to blasphemy from the Constitution in autumn 2010, at the same time tentatively planned for a referendum on [[Thirty-first Amendment of the Constitution (Children) Bill 2012|an amendment relating to children's rights]].<ref name="Coulter17032010">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0317/1224266442534.html|title=Ahern to propose blasphemy amendment|last=Coulter|first=Carol|date=17 March 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=23 October 2010}}</ref> Asked about this in the Dáil, Ahern did not offer any commitment, but said:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://debates.oireachtas.ie/DDebate.aspx?F=DAL20100325.xml&Node=H9-2|title=Referendum on Blasphemy|date=25 March 2010|work=Parliamentary Debates (Official Report – Unrevised)|publisher=Dáil Éireann|page=11|accessdate=23 October 2010}}</ref>
{{quote|the programme for Government did indicate the possibility of referendums on a number of issues ... If we were to have a number of referendums on one day, it would be appropriate to put to the people a question on the section of the Constitution relating to blasphemous and seditious libel.}}
In the event, no referendums were held before the dissolution of the [[30th Dáil]] in January 2011. Before [[Irish general election, 2011|the ensuing general election]], Atheist Ireland asked parties "Do you believe that blasphemy should be a criminal offence?" [[Fine Gael]], [[Sinn Féin]], and the [[Workers' Party (Ireland)|Workers' Party]] said no, while [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour]] and the [[Green Party (Ireland)|Green Party]] supported a referendum to remove the constitutional requirement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atheist.ie/information/2011-general-election/|title=How did the parties and candidates reply to our questions on secular policies?|last=Nugent|first=Michael|date=23 February 2011|work=[[Atheist Ireland]]|accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> After the election, the [[Government of the 31st Dáil|Fine Gael–Labour coalition]]'s programme for government promised a [[Constitutional Convention (Ireland)|Constitutional Convention]] to discuss potential amendments, including "Removing blasphemy from the Constitution".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finegael.ie/upload/ProgrammeforGovernmentFinal.pdf#page=17|title=Programme for Government|date=March 2010|publisher=Fine Gael|accessdate=10 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110409113343/http://www.finegael.ie/upload/ProgrammeforGovernmentFinal.pdf#page=17|archivedate=9 April 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>Convention on the Constitution, ''Sixth Report'' p.26</ref>
The Convention was established in December 2012, and received submissions on the blasphemy issue from various groups and individuals,<ref name="conv2014p4">{{cite web|url=https://www.constitution.ie/Submissions.aspx?cid=80|title=Blasphemy|work=Submissions received|publisher=Constitutional Convention|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> mostly in favour of abolition.<ref>Convention on the Constitution, ''Sixth Report'' p.4. "[T]here seemed to be an overwhelming support for the removal of the clause ... [T]he issue is regarded ... as part of a much wider debate, including the role of God and religion in the Constitution and the separation of Church and State"</ref><ref name="ConventionVideos">{{cite web|url=https://www.constitution.ie/ConventionVideos.aspx?cid=80|title=Blasphemy category|date=5 November 2013|work=Meeting videos|publisher=Constitutional Convention|accessdate=21 November 2013|location=Dublin}}</ref> The Irish Council of Churches, a coalition of the main [[Christianity in Ireland|Christian churches in Ireland]], described the provision as "largely obsolete".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.constitution.ie/AttachmentDownload.ashx?aid=2d5ac5af-2342-e311-8571-005056a32ee4|title=Submission from the Irish Council of Churches/Irish Inter-Church Meeting|last=McCullagh|first=Mervyn|date=31 October 2013|publisher=Constitutional Convention|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> The Convention considered the issue at its seventh [[plenary session]] on 2–3 November 2013.<ref>Convention on the Constitution, ''Sixth Report'' p.3</ref><ref name="ConventionCalendar">{{cite web|url=https://www.constitution.ie/AttachmentDownload.ashx?mid=873ff73a-11c9-e211-a5a0-005056a32ee4|title=Calendar for 2013|publisher=Constitutional Convention|accessdate=14 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/blasphemy-law-removal-considered-29719283.html |title=Blasphemy law removal considered |author=Press Association|date=2 November 2013 |work=[[Irish Independent]] |accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |url=https://www.constitution.ie/NewsDetails.aspx?nid=8dfc3d24-1842-e311-8571-005056a32ee4|title=Convention to consider the removal of the offence of blasphemy|date=31 October 2013|publisher=Constitutional Convention|accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref> Several submitters were invited to make presentations at the meeting.<ref name="ConventionVideos" /> There were expert presentations from university academics Neville Cox, Eoin O'Dell, and Maeve Cooke; the [[Knights of Saint Columbanus]], the [[Islamic Cultural Centre of Ireland]], and an [[National University of Ireland, Galway|NUIG]] PhD student argued in favour of retention; while Atheist Ireland, the [[Humanist Association of Ireland]], and the Irish Council of Civil Liberties argued for its removal.<ref name="ConventionVideos"/><ref>Convention on the Constitution, ''Sixth Report'' p.7. Cox and O'Dell's presentations are at pp.8–11 and 12–23 respectively.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2013/1102/484262-constitutitional-convention/|title=Constitutitional Convention reviews blasphemy - RTÉ News|date=2 November 2013|work=[[RTÉ.ie]]|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> Convention members voted 61–38 against retaining the existing Constitutional prohibition of blasphemy; 53–38 in favour of replacing it with a prohibition of "incitement to religious hatred"; and 50–49 against having a statutory prohibition of blasphemy.<ref name="conv2014p6">Convention on the Constitution, ''Sixth Report'' p.6</ref><ref name="it1582317">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/convention-recommends-replacing-blasphemy-offence-1.1582317|title=Convention recommends replacing blasphemy offence|last=Mac Cormaic|first=Ruadhán|date=3 November 2013|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> If a statutory prohibition were used, members voted 81–11 in favour of a new provision rather than the 2009 act.<ref name="conv2014p6"/>
In October 2014, [[Minister of State (Ireland)|Minister of State]] [[Aodhán Ó Ríordáin]] gave the official government response to the Convention's report on blasphemy, announcing that it had decided to hold a referendum on the issue.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sixth Report of the Constitutional Convention - Blasphemy: Statements |date=2 October 2014 |work=Dáil Éireann debates |publisher=Oireachtas |accessdate=15 April 2015 |url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail2014100200011?opendocument#J00100 }}</ref> In January 2015, Taoiseach [[Enda Kenny]] said there would not be a referendum on the issue before the [[Irish general election, 2016|next general election]], due by April 2016.<ref name="rte671900"/> He said that two referendums were already to be held in 2015, [[Thirty-fourth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|on marriage equality]] and [[Thirty-fifth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2015|reducing the age of candidacy for the presidency]], and any more might distract voters from focusing on the issues.<ref name="rte671900">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2015/0112/671900-news-in-brief/|title=News in Brief: Taoiseach rules out blasphemy referendum|date=12 January 2015|work=[[RTÉ.ie]]|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref>
After the election on 26 February 2016, [[2016 Irish government formation|protracted negotiations]] led to a [[Government of the 32nd Dáil|Fine Gael–independent government]] on 7 May with [[confidence and supply]] support from Fianna Fáil.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/enda-kenny-back-as-taoiseach-by-the-smallest-of-margins-398110.html|title=Enda Kenny back as Taoiseach by the smallest of margins|last=Ó Cionnaith|first=Fiachra|date=7 May 2016|work=Irish Examiner|accessdate=1 June 2016}}</ref> The government programme published on 11 May includes a commitment to holding a referendum on blasphemy.<ref name="Programme_for_Partnership_Government"/> After the May 2017 story about Stephen Fry, a [[Department of Justice (Ireland)|Department of Justice]] spokesperson said that it had undertaken "preliminary consultations and preparatory work" on the amendment, with future scheduling to be decided by the government.<ref name="it3075299">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/blasphemy-law-is-silly-and-a-little-embarrassing-says-harris-1.3075299|title=Blasphemy law is 'silly' and 'a little embarrassing' says Harris|last=Clarke|first=Vivienne|date=8 May 2017|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=8 May 2017}}</ref> [[Simon Harris (politician)|Simon Harris]], the [[Minister for Health (Ireland)|Minister for Health]], said the existing law was "silly, a little embarrassing and needs to be changed".<ref name="it3075299"/> In the Dáil [[Gerry Adams]] asked Enda Kenny whether a referendum would be held in 2017; Kenny replied "There are quite a number of referenda backed up, and they take time".<ref name="dail20170509"/> In September 2017, new Taoiseach [[Leo Varadkar]] gave an "indicative timeline" for planned referendums, with that on blasphemy in October 2018, simultaneous with [[Next Irish presidential election|the presidential election]] and two other referendums.<ref name="indicative20170926">{{cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2017/0926/907522-cabinet_referendums/|title=Referendum on Eighth Amendment expected next summer — Varadkar|date=26 September 2017|work=[[RTÉ.ie]]|accessdate=26 September 2017}}; {{cite press release |url=https://merrionstreet.ie/en/News-Room/News/Government_Sets_Indicative_Timetable_For_Referendums.html|title=Government Sets Indicative Timetable For Referendums|date=26 September 2017|work=MerrionStreet|publisher=Government of Ireland|accessdate=26 September 2017}}</ref>
In June 2018 the Government approved the holding of the referendum.<ref>{{cite news |title=Blasphemy referendum set to take place in October|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/ireland/2018/0612/970070-blasphemy/ |accessdate=12 June 2018 |work=[[RTÉ.ie]]|date=12 June 2018}}</ref> The [[Thirty-seventh Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018]] was [[first reading|formally introduced]] to the Dáil on 13 July.<ref>{{cite web |title=Thirty-seventh Amendment of the Constitution (Repeal of offence of publication or utterance of blasphemous matter) Bill 2018 |url=https://www.oireachtas.ie/en/bills/bill/2018/87/?tab=bill-text |website=Bills |publisher=Oireachtas |accessdate=5 September 2018 |language=en-ie |date=13 July 2018}}</ref> On 28 August the date of the Presidential election and hence the referendum was fixed for 26 October.<ref name="rte988011"/> On 5 September the other referendum planned for the same date was deferred until 2019.<ref>{{cite news |last1=McMorrow |first1=Conor |title=Referendum on place of women in the home deferred |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/politics/2018/0905/991714-women-in-the-place-referendum/ |accessdate=5 September 2018 |work=RTE.ie |date=5 September 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==Other laws and regulations== {{see also|Censorship in Ireland}} The Censorship of Films Act 1923 mandates the [[Irish Film Classification Office|Chief Censor]] to prohibit a film or scene "unfit for general exhibition in public by reason of its being indecent, obscene or blasphemous".<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1923/en/act/pub/0023/sec0007.html §7 When certificate to be granted by Official Censor.] Censorship of Films Act, 1923; Irish Statute Book</ref> A 1925 Amendment extended the power to ban advertisements for films.<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1925/en/act/pub/0021/sec0003.html §3. Prohibition of certain advertisements] Censorship of Films (Amendment) Act 1925; Irish Statute Book</ref> These powers are retained in the most recent legislation of 2008.<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2008/en/act/pub/0014/sec0070.html §70. Amendment of Censorship of Films Act 1923.] Civil Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2008; Irish Statute Book; {{cite web |url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/isbc/1923.html#a23_1923 |title=Commencements, Amendments, SIs for Acts of 1923 |page=Censorship of Films Act 1923 |nopp=Y |date=11 July 2017 |accessdate=31 July 2017}}</ref> ''[[Audrey Rose (film)|Audrey Rose]]'' was banned in 1977 on the grounds that its treatment of [[reincarnation]] amounted to "[[heresy]]".<ref>Rockett 2004, p.4: "It is regrettable that it ['Audrey Rose'] deals with the belief in the transmigration of the soul and for this reason must be rejected ... Heresy may be a strong word to use but it sums up the reason for rejection."</ref> The Censor (now called the Director of Film Classification) has wide discretion in interpreting the statutory criteria: ''[[Monty Python's Life of Brian]]'' was banned by [[Frank Hall (broadcaster)|Frank Hall]] in 1980 for being blasphemous;<ref name="bacik">{{cite journal|last=Bacik |first=Ivana |date=July 2003 |title=Free Speech, the Common Good and the Rights Debate |journal=The Republic |publisher=The Ireland Institute |issue=3: Culture in the Republic, Part One |url=http://theirelandinstitute.com/republic/03/html/bacik003.html }}</ref> when resubmitted in 1987 it was passed uncut by his successor Sheamus Smith.<ref>Rockett 2004, p.6</ref> These Acts apply only to cinema films; the Video Recordings Act 1989 does not include blasphemy as grounds for prohibition, but does include "incitement of religious hatred" as grounds for censorship or an outright ban (refusal of certification).<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1989/en/act/pub/0022/sec0003.html#zza22y1989s3 §3 Certification of video works.] Video Recordings Act 1989; Irish Statute Book</ref> In September 2016, reports that the lack of an Irish release for ''[[My Scientology Movie]]'' was due to the blasphemy laws were dismissed by ''[[The Irish Times]]'' as media flim-flam; Neville Cox said the laws were "of no relevance" to the situation.<ref name="it2807475">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/film/why-ireland-won-t-ban-louis-theroux-s-scientology-film-1.2807475|title=Why Ireland won't 'ban' Louis Theroux’s Scientology film |last=Clarke|first=Donald|date=28 September 2016|work=The Irish Times|accessdate=28 September 2016}}</ref>
The Censorship of Publications Acts (1929 and 1946) did not include blasphemy among possible grounds for banning, which were indecency, obscenity, promotion of "unnatural" [[contraception]] or abortion, and (in the case of [[periodical]]s) excessive focus on crime.<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1929/en/act/pub/0021/print.html Censorship of Publications Act 1929]; Irish Statute Book</ref><ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1946/en/act/pub/0001/print.html Censorship of Publications Act 1946]; Irish Statute Book</ref> In the debate on the 1946 Bill, Senator [[Louis O'Dea]] suggested adding blasphemy as a criterion.<ref>[http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0030/S.0030.194511140005.html Censorship of Publications Bill, 1945—Second Stage] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609123806/http://www.oireachtas-debates.gov.ie/S/0030/S.0030.194511140005.html |date=9 June 2011 }} Seanad Éireann – Volume 30–14 November 1945</ref>
The [[Advertising Standards Authority for Ireland]]'s voluntary code of conduct requires advertising to "avoid causing offence on grounds of ... religion" and not to "ridicule or exploit religious beliefs, symbols, rites or practices".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asai.ie/asaicode/section-3-general-rules/|title=Section 3: General rules|work=ASAI Code of Conduct 7th edition|publisher=Advertising Standards Authority for Ireland|pages=3.17, 3.19(e) |nopp=Y|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> A 2005 [[Paddy Power]] poster, parodying [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s [[The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)|''The Last Supper'']] with Jesus and the apostles in a casino, was withdrawn for breaching the religion guidelines as well as "taste and decency".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/business/2005/1005/68276-paddypower/|title=Paddy Power pulls Last Supper ads|date=5 October 2005|work=[[RTÉ.ie]]|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref>
The crime of [[sacrilege]] was defined, under the [[Larceny Act 1861]] and the [[Larceny Act 1916]], as [[breaking and entering]] a church ("place of divine worship") and committing any [[felony]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1916/act/50/section/24/enacted/en/html|title=Larceny Act 1916, Section 24|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref> Sacrilege was the charge used to prosecute theft from church [[poor box]]es. It was abolished as a separate crime by the Criminal Law (Jurisdiction) Act 1976 whereby several types of breaking and entering were replaced by the single crime of [[burglary]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1976/act/14/section/21/enacted/en/html|title=Criminal Law (Jurisdiction) Act 1976, Section 21|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail1975121000026#N15 |title=Private Members' Business — Criminal Law (Jurisdiction) Bill 1975 [Seanad]: Second Stage (Resumed) |date=10 December 1975|work=Dáil Éireann Debate|pages=Vol. 286 No. 8 p.26 cc.1379–1380 |nopp=Y|accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail1976021000026#N80|title=Criminal Law (Jurisdiction) Bill 1975 [Seanad]: Committee Stage (Resumed).|date=10 February 1976|work=Dáil Éireann Debate|pages=Vol. 287 No. 9 p.26 cc.1551–1552 |nopp=Y|accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref>
==Removal Of Constitutional Ban== On October 26, 2018, Ireland held a referendum which saw voters repeal the Blasphemy offence by a margin of 64.85% to 35.15%.<ref name=rteoct27 /> Nevertheless, blasphemy bans are still enforced under the 2009 Defamation Act.

'''Darwin Gross''' (1928–2008) was an American spiritual teacher who succeeded to the leadership of [[Eckankar]] in 1971 at the death of its founder [[Paul Twitchell]]. Gross officially took up the position of "Living ECK Master" on October 22, 1971 and appointed his successor [[Harold Klemp]] as Living ECK Master on October 22, 1981, though Gross later claimed Klemp failed to fully succeed to the position. Gross claimed to continue afterwards as the Living Eck Master, though he was precluded from continuing to use the Eck terminology.
==Biography==
Darwin Gross was born in 1928 in Denhoff, North Dakota. He was brought up in the [[Mennonite]] faith. As a young man, he served with the US 11th Airborne Division in Japan following World War II. Later, Gross worked as an engineer, acquiring gigs on the side as a jazz musician. He described in his books a childhood filled with encounters and learning from many of the spiritual teachers of Eckankar. The moment he found the writings of Paul Twitchell, he recognized this as the same teaching he had been receiving inwardly since childhood. He began studying Twitchell's mail-order discourses and soon wrote to Twitchell asking how he could help set up classes in the Portland, Oregon, area where he lived. Twitchell wrote back in November 1969, encouraging Gross to start some of the first ECK Satsang classes in the Northwestern United States. Gross continued taking on greater responsibilities with Eckankar and on many occasions traveled with Paul Twitchell to Eckankar Seminars. Gross gained the Eckankar title of leadership, the "Living ECK Master", upon Twitchell's death in October 1971.
On October 22, 1981, Darwin Gross's health problems led him to publicly appoint Harold Klemp as the Living ECK Master. Gross retained management responsibilities, running the corporate organization of Eckankar until 1983. In 1983 Gross was voted out of his position by the Eckankar Board of Directors under controversial circumstances involving unproven charges that he misappropriated Eckankar corporate funds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thetruth-seeker.com/scanindexsubtitleAcss.asp?SubtitleNo=28 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107160324/http://www.thetruth-seeker.com/scanindexsubtitleAcss.asp?SubtitleNo=28 |archivedate=2009-01-07 |df= }} United States District Court Oregon 1984 - Sri Darwin Gross vs Eckankar Corporation</ref> As Klemp entered an exclusive leadership role, the Eckankar corporate structure was changed in the State of California. This gave Klemp new authority in leadership as the only voting member of the Eckankar corporation.<ref>http://law.justia.com/california/codes/corp/9220-9226.html California corporate law code 9224(a)- Selection, Removal and Resignation of Directors</ref><ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20080626010318/http://www.geocities.com/bill_flavell/SriDarwinGrossHaroldKlemp10.14.89LetterPg5.jpg Darwin Gross letter Oct. 11, 1989</ref> This change, considered by Gross as a "hostile takeover" of the corporation, was formally filed in the State of California on June 20, 1985. The policies giving Klemp exclusive powers were changed in Eckankar's Minnesota corporate papers on January 30, 1987, and were also changed in the Eckankar Nevada corporate papers on December 21, 1987.<ref>http://www.hoovers.com/free/search/simple/xmillion/index.xhtml?what=4&what=4&query_string=Eckankar+Inc.&which=company&page=1&x=59&y=19&hoovcountry=us&bcl=1&state=NV Company Search Portal - Eckankar Inc Las Vegas, NV</ref>
Following the rift in ECKANKAR leadership in 1983, most members of Eckankar chose to follow Harold Klemp, but a number joined Darwin Gross and continue to learn under his new organization: "[[Ancient Teachings of the Masters|ATOM: Ancient Teachings of the Masters]]," [http://www.atomshop.org/main/index.php?option=com_frontpage&Itemid=1] in which he claimed to carry on the original teachings of Paul Twitchell.
In 1988, "The John Ankerberg Show" interviewed Gross in reference to his continued use of the term "Mahanta" (the inner spiritual master revered in Eckankar), and he said, "I always looked at myself as not the Mahanta but a vehicle for it.<ref>{{YouTube|GOu271fOwTQ|1988 Darwin Gross interview John Ankerberg TV}}</ref><ref>[http://www.johnankerberg.org/catalog/ATM.html John Ankerberg TV show archive] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511200312/http://www.johnankerberg.org/catalog/ATM.html |date=2008-05-11 }}</ref>"
Gross died on March 8, 2008 at the age of 80. According to the ATOM website, "Darwin’s Living Trust provides that his writings, music and unpublished works shall be held in trust to carry on his memory and life’s work as well as his predecessor’s, Paul Twitchell. The Teachings will continue to be made available to those who are interested in this most direct path to God." {{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}
== Casualties of Multiple Masters == One seldom revealed aftermath of the fork<ref>[http://www.oocities.org/eckcult/chapters/tmsm9.html Darwin Gross is Excommunicated]</ref> caused by the hostile corporate pushout of Darwin Gross from Eckankar was his many devoted and true believers. The caustic dilemma of this corporate in-fighting forced many eckists at the time to have to pick between Eckankar the religion and Darwin their ECK Master. This was akin to having a child decide if they loved their "good parent" more than their "bad parent" while being informed by the "good parent" that the "bad parent" was "truly bad". And though it may very well have been a wise business decision (at the time) by the board of directors of the Corporation of Eckankar to dump Darwin, the schism this situation caused opened Eckankar as a religion up to further divisions and splinter groups<ref>[http://www.masterpath.org/ Master Path]</ref> in the future.
==Legacy== During the decade of his leadership of Eckankar, Gross expanded the physical organization and membership of Eckankar substantially. His leadership was considered important for the followers of Eckankar during the time, prior to his 1983 expulsion from Eckankar.
Current ATOM students of Darwin Gross, who still study his discourses and books, consider Gross to be a very ancient master. Gross, like his teacher Paul Twitchell - the originator of Eckankar, is regarded as a spiritual master who descended from an ancient and direct line extending into a history that is said to predate the early history and existence of our planet and solar system. The mythology of the ECK Masters is outlined in Twitchell's ''The Spiritual Notebook''.[http://www.vielewelten.at/pdf_en/spiritual%20notebook.pdf][https://archive.org/details/PaulTwitchellSpiritualNotebook PDF]
==Books by Darwin Gross in Eckankar== * ''Consciousness: The Key to Life'', Menlo Park: IWP. (Out-of-print.) * ''The Eckankar Area Representative’s Handbook'', Menlo Park: Eckankar. (Out-of-print.) * ''Eckankar: A Way of Life'', Menlo Park: Eckankar. (Out-of-print.) * ''From Heaven to the Prairie'', Menlo Park: IWP. Autobiography. (Out-of-print.) * ''Gems of Soul'', Menlo Park: IWP. (Out-of-print.) * ''The Way of Eckankar'', Menlo Park: Eckankar. (Out-of-print.) * ''Your Right to Know'', Menlo Park: IWP. (Out-of-print.)
==Books by Darwin Gross after Eckankar== * ''The Atom'', ATOM. * ''The Atom Way of Life'', ATOM. * ''Awakened Imagination'', SOS. * ''Consciousness Is Life'', ATOM. * ''Forbidden Knowledge'', ATOM. * ''The Power of Awareness''. * ''You Can’t Turn Back'', SOS. * "Your Right To Choose", ATOM
==Books about Darwin Gross== * Burlin, Bernadine. ''Hero: Personal Experiences with Darwin Gross'', ATOM. * Burlin, Bernadine. ''My ECK Master Affair'', Menlo Park: IWP. (Out-of-print.) * Hammond, Alan. ''A Gift from the Master'', Menlo Park: IWP. (Out-of-print.)

'''The Federation of Zoroastrian Associations of North America''' (FEZANA) is a non-profit religious group registered in the state of [[Illinois]] and formed to function as the coordinating organization for [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrian]] Associations of North America. *FEZANA publishes a three-monthly magazine, FEZANA Journal which deals with such subjects as religion and youth, Zoroastrianism in North America, etc. *FEZANA organizes a (Zoroastrian) Excellence in Sports Scholarship (EXISS) each year, in a city in North America, in which every sportive Zoroastrian between the age of 10 and the age of 30 can participate.

[[Image:Tibet, mahakala, guardiano della dottrina sotto l'aspetto gur-gyi mgon-go, 1292.JPG|thumb|[[Mahakala]] statue, holding a [[Kartika (knife)|flaying knife]] (''kartika'') and [[kapala|skullcup]] (''kapala'')]] In [[Buddhism]], '''fierce deities''' are the fierce, wrathful or forceful (Tibetan: ''trowo'', Sanskrit: ''krodha'') forms of enlightened [[Buddha]]s, [[Bodhisattva]]s or [[Deva (Buddhism)|Devas]] (divine beings). Because of their power to destroy the obstacles to enlightenment, they are also termed ''krodha-vighnantaka'', "fierce destroyers of obstacles".Linrothe, Rob. Ruthless Compassion, 1999, page 12. Fierce deities are a notable feature of the iconography of [[Mahayana]] and [[Vajrayana|Vajrayana Buddhism]]. These types of deities first appeared in India during the late 6th century with its main source being the [[Yaksha]] imagery and became a central feature of Indian [[Tantric Buddhism]] by the late 10th or early 11th century.Linrothe, Rob. Ruthless Compassion, 1999, page x, 12. ==Overview== [[Image:Vajrayogini from Thangka.jpg|thumb|[[Vajrayogini]], a semi-wrathful [[dakini]] who is also known as ''[[Sarva|sarvabuddha]]ḍākiṇī'', the all-buddha Dakini.]] In non-Tantric traditions of [[Mahayana]] Buddhism, these beings are protector deities who destroy obstacles to the Buddhas and the Dharma, act as guardians against demons and gather together sentient beings to listen to the teachings of the Buddhas.Linrothe, Rob. Ruthless Compassion, 1999, page 13, 25. In [[Tantric Buddhism]], they are considered to be fierce and terrifying forms of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas themselves. Enlightened beings may take on these forms in order to protect and aid confused sentient beings.Thurman, Robert. The Tibetan Book of the Dead: Liberation Through Understanding in the Between, page 149. They also represent the energy and power that is needed in order to transform negative mental factors into wisdom and compassion.Berzin, Alexander; Making Sense of Tantra, https://studybuddhism.com/en/advanced-studies/vajrayana/tantra-theory/making-sense-of-tantra/tantric-imagery#peaceful-and-forceful-figuresLinrothe, Rob. Ruthless Compassion, 1999, page xi. They represent the power and compassion of enlightened activity which uses multiple skillful means ([[upaya]]) to guide sentient beings as well as the transformative element of tantra which uses negative emotions as part of the path. According to [[Chogyam Trungpa]], "wrathful yidams work more directly and forcefully with passion, aggression, and delusion - conquering and trampling them on the spot."Chögyam Trungpa. The Collected Works of Chögyam Trungpa: Volume 3, Shambala, 2003, page 438. In Tantric Buddhist art, fierce deities are presented as terrifying, demonic looking beings adorned with human skulls and other ornaments associated with the charnel ground, as well as being often depicted with sexually suggestive attributes. According to Rob Linrothe, the sensual and fierce imagery represents "poison as its own antidote, harnessed obstacles as the liberating force" and notes that they are "metaphors for the internal yogic processes to gain enlightenment".Linrothe, Rob. Ruthless Compassion, 1999, page xi-xii. ==Tantric Deities== ===Yidams=== In Indo-Tibetan [[Vajrayana]], [[Yidam]]s are divine forms of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. The tantric practitioner is initiated into the mandala of a particular chosen deity (Sanskrit: ''Iṣṭa-devatā'') and practices complex [[sadhana]]s (meditations) on the deity for the purpose of personal transformation.[[Robert Buswell Jr.|Buswell, Robert E.]]; [[Donald S. Lopez, Jr.|Lopez, Donald S.]] (2013). ''The Princeton dictionary of Buddhism''. Princeton and Oxford: Princeton University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-691-15786-3}}. This [[Deity Yoga]] practice is central to tantric forms of Buddhism such as [[Tibetan Buddhism]]. Yidams can be peaceful, fierce and "semi-fierce" (having both fierce and peaceful aspects). Fierce deities can be divided into male and female categories.[http://www.khandro.net/deities_wrathful.htm Wrathful Deities] The [[Heruka]]s ([[Standard Tibetan|Tb]]. ''khrag 'thung'', lit. "blood drinker") are enlightened masculine beings who adopt fierce forms to express their detachment from the world of ignorance, such as [[Yamantaka]], [[Cakrasaṃvara Tantra|Cakrasamvara]], [[Mahākāla]], or [[Kīla (Buddhism)|Vajrakilaya]]. [[Dakini]]s ([[Standard Tibetan|Tb]]. ''khandroma'', "sky-goer") are their feminine counterparts, sometimes depicted with a heruka and sometimes as independent deities. The most prevalent wrathful [[dakini]]s are [[Vajrayogini]] and [[Vajravārāhī]]. ====Gallery==== File:Yamantaka Vajrabhairav.jpg|[[Yamantaka]], also known as Vajrabhairava. File:Yamantaka, Fear-Striking Vajra, Lord of Death on a water buffalo, Vajrayana Buddhism.jpg|[[Yamantaka]] statue File:Yamantaka.jpg|Yamantaka [[thangka]] File:Ekajati.jpg|[[Ekajati]], also known as Blue Tara or Ugra Tara. File:Chakrasamvara - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Chakrasamvara]], a semi-wrathful deity, depicted in [[yab-yum]] with consort File:Chakrasamvara 01.jpg|Tibetan statue of standing [[Chakrasamvara]] and consort File:6-armiger Mahakala.jpg|6-arm [[Mahakala]] File:Lhasa 1996 190.jpg|Painted statue of [[Mahakala]] File:Vajrakilaya (8557221604).jpg|[[Vajrakilaya]] File:Dancing Vajravarahi (Dorje Pagmo) LACMA M.90.195.jpg|Dancing [[Vajravarahi]] (''Dorje Pagmo'') File:Vajrayogini statue from Nepal, 18th century, gilt bronze, Honolulu Museum of Art.JPG|[[Vajrayogini]] File:Troma Nagmo closeup.jpg|Troma Nagmo File:Hevajra-Tibetan.jpg|[[Hevajra]] File:The Wrathful Deities of the Guhyagarbha Tantra.png|The Herukas of the [[Guhyagarbha Tantra]] File:Kalachakra_and_his_Core_Assembly_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg|[[Kalachakra]] and Core Assembly. File:Beijing 2009-1027.jpg|[[Kalachakra]] statue File:Samye16.JPG|[[Kurukullā]] File:Yamari, Rakta (Buddhist Deity) 16th century Boston MFA.jpg|[[Rakta Yamari]] ===Wisdom Kings=== In [[East Asian Buddhism]], [[Wisdom King]]s ([[Sanskrit]] ''vidyarāja''), are seen as divine manifestations of the Buddhas, who act as protectors, messengers and defenders of the Buddhist Dharma.Baroni, Helen Josephine (2002). ''The illustrated encyclopedia of Zen Buddhism''. New York: Rosen Pub. Group. p. 100. {{ISBN|0-8239-2240-5}}. In East Asian [[Vajrayana]] and [[Chinese Esoteric Buddhism]] the five wisdom kings are manifestations of the [[Five Tathagatas]]. ====Gallery==== File:Acala_at_Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple_and_Museum.JPG|[[Acala]], "The Immovable One" - manifestation of [[Vairocana|Buddha Mahavairocana]] File:Kongo Yasha wood statue.jpg|[[Vajrayaksa]], "The Devourer of Demons" - manifestation of [[Amoghasiddhi|Buddha Amoghasiddhi]] File:Daiitoku myoo painting.jpg|[[Yamantaka|Vajrabhairava]], "The Defeater of Death" - manifestation of [[Amitābha|Buddha Amitābha]] File:Gundari.jpg|The Wisdom king [[Kuṇḍali|Kundali]], "The Dispenser of Heavenly Nectar" - manifestation of [[Ratnasambhava|Buddha Ratnasambhava]] File:Gōzanze Kiburi-ji.jpg|[[Trailokyavijaya]], "The Conqueror of The Three Planes" - manifestation of [[Akshobhya|Buddha Akshobhya]]

==The Protectors== The Protectors ([[Sanskrit]] ''pāla'') or [[Dharmapala|Dharmapāla]] (Dharma protectors), are powerful beings, often [[Deva (Buddhism)|Devas]] or [[Bodhisattva]]s who protect the Buddhist religion and community from inner and outer threats and obstacles to their practice.''Heart Jewel'': The Essential Practices of Kadampa Buddhism, pages 71-3, Tharpa Publications (2nd. ed., 1997) {{ISBN|978-0-948006-56-2}} A Dharmapala can also be a [[Garuda]], [[Nāga]], [[Yaksha]], [[Gandharva]], or [[Asura]].Robert E. Buswell Jr.; Donald S. Lopez Jr. (2013). [https://books.google.com/books?id=DXN2AAAAQBAJ ''The Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism'']. Princeton University Press. pp. 249–250. {{ISBN|978-1-4008-4805-8}}. Other categories of Protectors include the [[Four Heavenly Kings|Lokapālas]] or "Four Heavenly Kings" and [[Kshetrapala|{{IAST|Kṣetrapālas}}]] or "Protectors of the Region". ===Eight Dharmapalas=== A common Tibetan grouping of Dharmapāla is 'The Eight [[Dharmapala]]s' ({{bo|t=དྲག་གཤེད|w=drag gshed}}), who are understood to be the defenders of [[Buddhism]]. They are [[supernatural]] beings with the rank of [[bodhisattva]] who "are supposed to wage war without any mercy against the demons and enemies of Buddhism".{{cite web|url=http://www.exoticindiaart.com/wrathful.htm|title=Wrathful Guardians of Buddhism - Aesthetics and Mythology|date=February 2001|accessdate=2008-08-31}} The Eight Dharmapala are:Pearlman, Ellen. Tibetan Sacred Dance: A Journey into the Religious and Folk Traditions, page * [[Yama (East Asia)|Yama]], the god of death * [[Mahākāla|Mahakala]], the Great Black One * [[Yamantaka]], the conqueror of death * [[Vaiśravaṇa]] or [[Kubera]], the god of wealth * [[Hayagriva (Buddhism)|Hayagriva]], the Horse-necked one * [[Palden Lhamo]], female protectress of Tibet * White [[Brahma]] or ''Tshangs pa'' * [[Begtse]], a war god from Mongolia. ===Gallery=== File:Buddha-Vajrapani-Herakles.JPG|Greco-Buddhist [[Vajrapani]]-[[Heracles]] File:Vajrapani_American_Museum_of_Natural_History.jpg|[[Vajrapani]] File:Palden_Lhamo,_Tawang_Monastery.jpg|[[Palden Lhamo]] File:Todaiji13s4592.jpg|Japanese [[Vaiśravaṇa]] (Bishamonten), one of the four Heavenly Kings, at [[Todaiji]] File:Guardian of Phra Meru Mas of Bhumibol Adulyadej - Vessavana (left side).jpg|A thai depiction of [[Vaiśravaṇa]] (Vessavana). File:GanpatiTibetan.jpg|[[Ganapati]] File:Citipati-buddhist-deity.jpg|[[Citipati (Buddhism)|Citipati]] File:Yellow Yama (?) and Consort on Bull, Nyingmapa Buddhist or Bon Ritual Card LACMA AC1998.253.1.jpg|Yama, lord of death File:Hayagriva_Samye_Ling_July_09.jpg|[[Hayagriva]], the "horse-necked" File:Rahula and his Assembly - Google Art Project.jpg|Rahula, an oath-bound protector of [[Dzogchen]] File:Korea-Gangwon-Woljeongsa Heavenly King 1690-07.JPG|Virūpāksa - King of the West, one of the Four Heavenly Kings at Wolijeongsa, Korea == See also == * [[Buddhist deities]] * [[Chinese mythology]] * [[Hindu mythology]] * [[Japanese mythology]] * [[Korean mythology]] * [[Vajrapani]] * [[Vajravarahi]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.exoticindiaart.com/wrathful.htm Wrathful Guardians of Buddhism - Aesthetics and Mythology] * [http://www.khandro.net/deities_wrathful.htm Wrathful Deities] * [http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15324coll10/id/101557 ''Sacred visions : early paintings from central Tibet''], fully digitized text from The Metropolitan Museum of Art libraries {{Buddhism topics}} [[Category:Buddhist deities]] [[Category:Buddhist culture]] [[Category:Lists of deities]] [[Category:Vajrayana]]
